151293888.review: Fighting games aren't my cup of tea but I saw the game-play and I absolutely fell in love with it. The game plays out more like a game of chess and even with the few characters, game-play never felt repetitive, the mechanics and everything is really cool as well with how they managed to turn a fighting game into a turn based game. With regular fighting games it is really hard for beginners to get into with learning inputs for combos etc but with the moves being one button press and the prediction mechanic that shows what the move do, it lets beginners understand how the moves work and what their actions would result in. Really great game to transition into learning fighting games gradually with most fighting game mechanics present and overall really enjoyed it, especially with replays that makes you feel like those stick man fight animations on YouTube with ungodly reflexes that are neigh impossible in real time.

Over the past few years life has been tough, with a lot of things going on i eventually stumbled upon this game in its early stages on Itch.io. after playing this game with friends on itch we eventually moved to steam where this beauty was for a cheap price, (this helped since i was broke from my massive pickle jar collection i was building in my basement fridge).
this game truly helped me by making me use my brain instead of mindlessly button mashing my keyboard and throwing it through a wall... ever since my wife left with the kids because i spent their college funds on more pickles to fill my basement I've found closure in this game after a long time. even through the messy divorce and her taking half my assets, (yes including the pickles), i was left with little to nothing, while i spent paycheck to paycheck reclaiming each and every jar she took away from me, and with each new jar i got that was filled with the glorious nectar of god known as pickles, i was able to overcome a mighty depression which grasped my life and almost made me lose faith in my collection returning to its glory days, while this game was there with me through my journey.

150823797.review:
[h1]I saw some high-tier monster gameplay on youtube and... Wait, this game is turn-based?[/h1]

YOMI Hustle, AKA Your Only Move Is Hustle, is a turn-based fighting game that draws inspiration from stick-man fight animations, high-level fighting games, and chess.

This is a game of prediction. Is your foe going to attack? Grab? dodge? or jump? Sometimes these are important, other times you can wing it.

[h1]Cowboys, Ninjas and Robots, oh my!... And a wizard too.[/h1]

The vanilla game currently has four characters - Ninja, Cowboy, Wizard, and Robot. 

Ninja is the rushdown character with short-ranged attacks and a solid projectile collection. Harder to play for beginners
Cowboy is the mid-ranged, teleport-heavy all-around-fighter who is easier to pick up for beginners.
Wizard is the projectile-heavy zoner with a few mix-up specials and highly-trap-oriented supers.
Robot is the grappler, with awkward movement, heavy, powerful grabs, longer-ranged ground game, and a remote-controlled bomb that you can kick around like an exploding basketball.

[h1]Uh... How do I use this move? How does this character work?[/h1]

This game lacks a tutorial. Although it's gotten better on displaying how many frames a move takes and how moves work, you'll still need to take some time in single player to understand how your characters work. You can look up guides on youtube and wiki.gbl.gg/w/YomiHustle

The most important things to learn for anyone looking to get into this:
 
-- Use the DI wheel, it'll save you if you're stuck in a combo.
-- WHIFF CANCEL SPARINGLY! You cannot block after a whiff! It's also a waste to whiff after you and your foe get ready in four frames or less.
-- Burst can save you, but it can be parried - this is dangerous if your burst gets parried.
-- If you try and block mid-combo to predict a burst, but your opponent does nothing, you are vulnerable to attack.
-- Never underestimate a foe who has less health but more super bars than you.

[h1]Mods? More characters? Wait is that Sans Undert-[/h1]

YOMI Hustle has an extensive modding scene. Skins, Full-on Characters, stages, game modes, even ranked! I recommend trying out vanillia for at least a little bit before you go full-on into the modding scene, as many of the modded characters suffer from "I want my beloved main to be more powerful than anything" syndrome that you see in other customizable fighting games.

[h1]Hustle?[/h1]

Yes. It's a Great game. Worth it for it's meager price alone.

150785779.review:
The epitome of punk rock video games. What looks like a half-assed stick fighter knockoff is an incredibly detailed, intricate deconstruction of the fighting game genre. It is hyper rock-paper-scissors. It's rock-paper-scissors-hadouken-kill process.

Just buy it, it's so god damn cheap it might as well be free -- and buy it for a buddy, too. Who knows, they might like it more than you. What's important, to me, is that this kind of thing is given ubiquity, to help make people wonder *why* they are attracted to a game or genre ----

For instance, I do *not* like fighting games. Generally speaking, I find them banal, despite all the mounting evidence to their own twitchy intricacy. I love X-Com! I'm a strategy guy! And I love Yomi Hustle. This thing is "essence of Street Fighter", with a strong base of Mortal Kombat, cut open and splayed, and all participants can see it's delicious, meaty interior. Even with four characters, each match is unique.

And don't even GET me started on this nutso-ass community. LOOK AT THE MODS FOR THIS THING. It's only a matter of time until we get the Scooby-Doo characters, or Ayanami Rei added to the roster.

And the best part? When a match is over you are treated to the entire fight *in real time*, and it looks *AWESOME*. I will just boot this shit up to WATCH a replay of a fight I've had. That's how bad this thing's got me.

It's good. Incredibly good.

9/10 nerf robot

For such a low price tag, I'd highly recommend.

150649430.review:
If you've spent long lonely hours of a late-summer day of the year 2013 watching Super Smash Brothers Melee TAS fights and wishing you would ever manage to even LICK the amount of skill from the two supposed players in them, then this game is your bread and butter.

It concurrently has 4 playable characters. which for a fighting game is a miniscule amount if you've played one after 1987, but the characters you do have are sharpened and designed to a laser-point accuracy, each with a viable and yet, unique play-style. doing endless 1v1's against yourself does get a bit boring at a point, but that just means its time to get out of weenie-hut-jr's and go get manhandled by the multiplayer community. Not-saying getting manhandled is un-fun though.
Fighting against other players is a totally unique gaming experience in my books, it feels way more like chess but at the same time you're constantly thinking about what the opponent tries to think what you will do, it gets to the point where doing the obvious thing is sometimes the unexpected option because you both start to expect the unexpected if that makes any sense.

TL:DR Fighting game chess for TAS-fans

150556481.review:
After enough playing around with friends, I can certainly say there are some things that new players should be informed of:

"No Training Mode Required"
You will need to take some time to play with each character in single player, especially if this is your first time playing, each function takes some time to understand, and there are automatic mechanics which make a big difference in how you fight, such as punishing fleeing, and decreasing damage the longer a player is trapped in a combo. Locking in is not undo-able, once you hit lock in, your move that turn has been decided, click with caution (space bar also triggers lock in).

If you want time to plan your actions, this is not a fast game
As one of my friends have said, this game is similar to chess, unless you challenge yourself and set the timer to 5 seconds, or even instant kill, you will be in for a long ride. My best advice for those with the patience, please, if the game gives you no options, just change your DPI (optional) and remember to lock in, even if you have no moves, you and your opponent will still need to lock in to progress the game.
(Do NOT set the timer high if you're going to forget to lock in constantly)

Wait wait wait, you mentioned "DPI", what is that?
DPI is a mechanic which allows you to change the momentum of your character when you are hit by an opponents attack, it's possibly one of the only methods to escaping a deadly combo (unless you just want to tough it out), once again, you will need to play around in single player before jumping into multiplayer.

The Topic of Mods(/Addons)
You will inevitably get bored of the 4 character options given to you, they're fun, don't get me wrong, but eventually you'll want something new. There's a few things you should know about modding (but they're pretty general for most modded games)
- YOU WILL NEED A CHARACTER LOADER
There is one already available in the workshop, it's almost every character modder's go-to, but you will need that before you're able to use most modded characters
- LOAD THE CHARACTERS IN SINGLE PLAYER
When you first download a new character, you need to go into single player and select it, this will allow the game to load it, and create a cache file for it (so that you don't need to reload it every time you open the game). This is the most stable way to load a character without issue. If your character stops working and seems to be breaking your game, there's methods to deleting the character's cache file to allow you to reload it.
- MODS ARE NOT STABLE
This is just given, but there's TONS of conflicting mods, sometimes even the mods conflict with vanilla (Vixen (modded) vs Cowboy (vanilla)). The game does not have addon share, so if you want to play a modded character with friends, all of you will need to download the SAME mod.
- MANY MODS ARE OP
Mods are not guaranteed to be balanced... that's it, that's all I can say really. Just find mods that work for you and your friends.

150334517.review:
[h1]do you enjoy fighting games but hate inputting all those complex inputs?[/h1]
[h2]do you constantly find yourself getting smacked upside the head for not being fast enough?[/h2]
well, YOMI Hustle is a great game for you!

by removing the aspect of reaction and replacing it with turn-based movements, YOMIH provides insight into fighting games that will genuinely help you understand fundamental concepts and get better overall.

YOMI Hustle expands on turn-based fighting in such a unique way that, once you grasp how the game works, it becomes a matter of tactics and prediction.
Some have called it "fighting game chess", and I believe this is a very accurate way to describe the gameplay.

In terms of graphic fidelity, it reminds me of the old stickman animations on youtube- except it's a game!
It's quite wonderful to see the explosive and hasty fight scenes work out; oftentimes one player will just narrowly catch the win, but other times one party will simply get pummeled.

Not to mention the modding community, striving to create characters that burn with passion. To the spriters and developers who work hard every day to provide cool custom content, thank you so much!

In any case, YOMI Hustle is an amazing turn-based fighter that takes a rather arduous element intrinsic to fighting games and spins the genre in a unique, lovely direction.

I can't wait to see what Ivy Sly has in store for this game, and it's worth every dollar ♡

149020040.review:
¡Prepárate para sumergirte en el cautivador mundo de Yomi Hustle, una joya indie que, aunque no goza de la fama masiva, te brinda una experiencia de juego absolutamente épica! Tanto si prefieres enfrentarte a desafíos en línea como si te apetece compartir la diversión con amigos, este juego te proporcionará una satisfacción inigualable.

La jugabilidad, aunque inicialmente parece tener límites, te sumerge en una experiencia tan inmersiva y emocionante que te dejará con ganas de más. A pesar de algunos pequeños tropiezos, como la música que podría ser mejor o el equilibrio entre personajes que necesita ajustes, la esencia del juego brilla de manera inigualable.

Pero espera, ¡aquí viene lo realmente emocionante! Gracias a una comunidad apasionada y creativa, los mods transforman Yomi Hustle en algo verdaderamente espectacular. La imaginación de los modders no tiene límites, y las posibilidades que ofrecen sus creaciones son infinitas. Con estos mods, el juego alcanza alturas inexploradas, desatando una nueva dimensión de diversión y desafíos.

Y, ¿qué pasaría si estas increíbles ideas de los modders se integraran en el juego original? Imagina una experiencia de juego donde tus sueños y deseos se hacen realidad, al igual que en Minecraft con sus millones de mods que son desaprovechados y finalmente no se implementan en el juego original. Creo firmemente que Yomi Hustle tiene el mismo potencial, una oportunidad brillante para la comunidad y el creador del juego de unirse y crear algo verdaderamente asombroso.

En resumen, Yomi Hustle no es simplemente un juego, ¡es un viaje cautivador lleno de posibilidades emocionantes! ¿Estás listo para unirte a esta aventura y descubrir un mundo donde la creatividad y la diversión no tienen límites? ¡Prepárate para una experiencia de juego que cambiará tu forma de ver los videojuegos para siempre!
Le doy 4,7 Hornys sobre 5.

148923846.review:
Really great addictive turn based fighting game. 

I've tried to get into most fighting games over the years as i like the idea of 1v1 games but always bounced off them after spending hours trying to learn combos only to get destroyed immediately online by people who have been playing for years and have ingrained fighting game fundamentals and eventually just give up as its difficult to notice what you're doing wrong when you're a human pinball. YOMI hustle massively cuts down the frustration with its turn based mechanic. 

While the UI can look a bit overwhelming its actually surprisingly intuitive and you'll be able to understand the basics after a couple of rounds, Though i did find that there is often no explanation of certain core mechanics as well as options around character move-sets. You're left to work it out yourself or more likely have to look it up. (I was surprised at how much of my character i wasn't using as intended until I looked up their abilities and i noticed most other beginners were doing the same )

I've only played a dozen or so hours as of writing this review but I'm fairly surprised at how much my play has improved by just experimenting with my characters kit, noticing how other people play & getting tips from my opponents during the games. The rounds are quite long and can feel like a bit of a drag if your getting mopped up but I found in the beginner lobbies most of my matches are pretty even & it definitely has that one more round feel if you managed to pull off a few cool combos or get a close win.

The base game currently only has 4 characters, I'm unsure if this is by the games stripped down design or because it seems the game is worked on by a solo dev but currently i feel that it works in its favour and hope there are too many added down the line. After playing for a few hours you'll have a rough idea of all the characters general play style,capabilities & their go to moves which i think is essential for the back & forth chess feeling of the game. All the characters play completely differently and have their own specific mechanics, strengths & weaknesses even the basic movement is quite character specific and at least for me with how consistent improvement can be you'll find yourself quite invested in focusing in on with whichever specific character you gravitate to. 

Outside of that the game seems to have a pretty good community, lobbies are active, people will often want to chat during the game and generally will give you some really helpful pointers if you mention your new. There also seems to be quite a lot of workshop support for additional characters/stages etc which seems popular and can provide tons of options for characters if you find the base ones are limited.

148760665.review:
I really did enjoy this game, the workshop compatibility is great and round style favored fast, quick thinking matches that were easy to sit down and play. But the developer seems to want this to be a different game, because in the recent update to 1.18, they removed a lot of the consequences for just blocking, over and over. This removes a big part of the game, blocks were a risk, and you primarily avoided damage with careful movement, and frame timings that were made easier by the style of game.

Now, matches are much much slower, and you are punished a lot for aggression. not the mention, move cancel is on by default, which just makes for an annoying thing to toggle every frame. I can't recommend this game anymore, at least until things are fixed or adjusted further.

Edit 1:
Well I can say the mechanics have gotten a little work, but really this one is aimed at the developer. As of posting I was one of many registered for the Olympus tournament qualifiers. Typically you would expect an online tournament to provide players a timespan to check in and register, with emails and notice sent in advance of the tournament. The only email I and many others would get was at the moment of the start of the tournament. Naturally I wasn't sitting on my email at the time, and expecting more notice than a minute, I missed the start.

I can't say how many people experienced a similar confusion, but given the tournament is in full swing now, I imagine I'll find out soon. The lack of communication in this attempt at invigorating the Yomi community is frankly just dissapointing, and I hope the team will improve with successive events, rather than let this be their template moving forwards.

148684034.review:
The only Stickman game that is more than just rough at the beginning, but god damn worth the experience.

Your Only Move Is Hustle (YOMIH for short),
is a 2D Turn-Based Strategy fighting game where you and another player fight against each other as different characters that you can choose. The game tests your experience, thinking and prediction that you build up the more you get invested into the game. At the end of each battle you get a satisfying replay, like shown in the trailer/preview of the game.

"The Struggle Of Each Beginner"

The game is extremely overwhelming at first upon seeing the UI at first. You dont understand a thing, meaning you are heavily dependant of other helping you out understanding the ropes of the game, watching tutorial videos urself or simply trying ur best to understand it on ur own. Not saying that its hard to get into but most certaintly is rough, especially if you fight against other already experienced players. Getting the UI down is one thing but then learning and understanding how each mechanic actually works is another. Its not something that should stop you from playing the game though, you dont need to spend hours on end to just understand the basics. 

"Nice Community"

In my 136 Hours I spend playing and hanging out in the game, I can say that the community is very nice, atleast the Non-Modding Community (More to that later). I personally met 2 people that were really toxic towards me while 99% of others players were really fun chatting with and having discussions about the moves and fight we are currently having is very informative to improve. You get to be very goofy with another player, either chatting some funny shit how we beat eachother up or just trying to get a nice replay together. Obiviously thats only my experience so far and it really depends on how you behave around this chess-on-crack game. But usually the worst that happens is when you or your opponent rage quits.

"Extremely Cool Workshop"

If you want to take a look on what the community can make just take a glimpse at the workshop. You can test out other (famous) video game characters and even fight other players with them. I even saw entire game modes implemented or cool design changes that you can use. The community takes his time to be a creative with things because of the simplicity of the game. Many players, if not the most, are playing "Modded" YOMIH. I personally just stick with the Non-Modded experience unless I really want to do something fun or interesting.

Absolutely recommending the game!

148562097.review:
Rock Paper Scissors for zoomers

------
non joke review:

I feel like Yomi Hustle fails on its premise, that is, the depth/complexity of a fighting game without requiring precision, fast-based input, allowing an accessible and exciting entry into the strategy of fighting games.

It fails on this premise because of complexity creep, and a pattern of intentional design decisions to appeal to an extreme niche of players. It is probably "competitive creep", where competitive players are prioritized over casuals, but in doing so casual gameplay is damaged.

In this game's early, early betas, when it was a free demo, there was significantly less precision options, and the game benefited from this simplicity. You simply had to pick a move, your opponent picked a move, and you get to see what happens. There was a much higher focus on movement. It was much more of a movement fighter like smash bros. or rivals of aether, rather than a game with more limited neutral. Recent changes however have greatly increased the overall complexity and load for simple actions, as well as pushing fighters closer together to discourage movement.

- You now have to pick which frame to guard on, instead of just waiting and hitting guard.
- Many, MANY moves now have secondary or tertiary inputs, on top of most characters having secondary movement inputs each turn.
- The introduction of sadness, priority etc. there's so much hidden mechanics that are not clearly demonstrated to the player, that unless someone goes and reads the historical patch notes or has played patch-to-patch, there's no real explanation of how things work.

Compare this to the idealized YOMI Hustle where you have an amount of fixed actions, each with their own frame-data, or the option to wait, defend or move. Somehow this simpler version of the game realizes its goals of accessibility without being overly bogged down by complicated, poorly explained mechanics.

I find myself going back and playing the earlier demos which are significantly less mechanically complicated and enjoying them more. While those versions may be less "balanced" and have more bugs, glitches, etc., they were accessible for a softcore audience like myself, instead of the competitive scene that this game seems to have found as its core audience.

148161275.review:
This game may seem a little bare bones at first, but it is really fun and only costs 5 dollars, so give it a shot. I play a lot of traditional fighting games, but I really like YOMI because it has no execution barrier and allows you to plan out your combos to execute them almost perfectly.
Pros:
-Very Accessible
-Cool and flashy combos
-In-depth character customization system
Cons:
-Slow paced when actually playing (When you are deciding the outcome of the match, not watching the replay)
-One stage
-Only 4 characters
Now, the last two cons are only in the base game. You can use the steam workshop to get tons of custom characters and stages to make your experience much more fun. You should really give this game a shot.

148127830.review:
I would highly recommend this game, 
you can ignore most of the negative reviews as it is primarily people who went into the game without bothering to figure out the controls and expecting to win, resulting in them getting their **** kicked and getting salty over it. To anyone actually considering playing the game, I would recommend watching some youtube videos. First about general mechanics and then the specific character you would like to play. I personally recommend the video Your Only Guide To Yomi Hustle (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1NH1ko61rkw) as it is only 30 minutes long and provides you with a good grasp of the essential mechanics. I would suggest putting on some music to keep positive as sometimes you can get quite gruelling matches, but the most important thing to remember is that if you mentally accept defeat you will not see opportunities you normally would if you had a better mindset. Try not to be too disheartened by losing as you will never improve if you always win. Saving the replays of your fights, even the ones where you lose, are good as you can slowly analyse your performance and identify things you could of done differently. Joining the offical YOMI Hustle discord server is also recommended as you can find alot of answers to the questions you will undoubtedly have. Sometimes Your Only Move Is Hustle.
Don't be salty

147660958.review: A great fighting game for turn based/real-time strategy fans. It can be both frustrating and rewarding depending on your opponent. It's mainly a multiplayer game that has mod support but separates mod users and non mod users. It uses a lot of fighting game terminology so looking into that can help immensely playing the game. Primarily, you want to learn about frame advantage and learn that the less frames it take for you to make a move, the better! Once that's done, then it becomes a reading game where you want to anticipate your opponents move. Finally, there's the satisfaction of your game playing out in real time. So an approximately 30 minute game will play out in less than a minute to make your matches look like epic fight scenes. Many mention this to be like chess and they're not wrong with some of the calculations that need to be made to be victorious. It's unfortunate that the game might just stay as an indie gem but it is brilliant on its execution. While online is still active as of this review, it is also more enjoyable versus friends!
